Literature Review: Statistical Data Privacy (SDP) has emerged as a critical field of study in response to the dual demands of open data sharing and the protection of sensitive information. This literature review explores the foundational concepts, methodologies, and challenges within SDP, focusing on the two predominant frameworks: Statistical Disclosure Control (SDC) and Differential Privacy (DP). Both frameworks aim to balance the trade-off between data utility and privacy, albeit through different approaches and theoretical underpinnings. Statistical Disclosure Control (SDC) has been the traditional approach to protecting data privacy, focusing on modifying data to prevent the disclosure of sensitive information while retaining as much data utility as possible. Techniques such as data masking, aggregation, and suppression are commonly employed within SDC to achieve this balance. The effectiveness of these techniques is often evaluated based on the risk of disclosure versus the loss of data utility, with various metrics developed to quantify these aspects (Duncan & Pearson, 1991). Differential Privacy (DP), introduced by Dwork et al. (2006), offers a more formal and mathematically rigorous framework for privacy. DP provides strong privacy guarantees by ensuring that the inclusion or exclusion of a single individual in the dataset has a negligible effect on the output of any analysis performed on the data. This is achieved through the addition of carefully calibrated noise to the data or the results of queries, with the level of noise determined by the privacy parameter ε. The smaller the value of ε, the stronger the privacy guarantee, but at the cost of reduced data utility. Despite their differences, both SDC and DP face common statistical challenges, particularly in the realm of inference. The process of sanitizing data, whether through SDC or DP techniques, introduces bias and variance into the data, complicating the task of making valid statistical inferences. Researchers have developed methods to design optimal data release mechanisms that minimize these effects while adhering to privacy constraints (Smith, 2011). Additionally, there is ongoing work on adjusting existing sanitized outputs to produce new estimators that are both statistically valid and optimal (Rubin, 1993). Uncertainty quantification is another critical area of research in SDP, as it is essential for understanding the impact of sanitization mechanisms on statistical inferences. Techniques for quantifying uncertainty must account for the bias and variance introduced by privacy-preserving mechanisms, requiring innovative approaches to statistical analysis (Wasserman & Zhou, 2010). The field of SDP is rich with open research problems, ranging from the development of new privacy-preserving mechanisms to the exploration of the theoretical limits of privacy and utility. As data continues to play an increasingly central role in society, the importance of advancing our understanding and capabilities in SDP cannot be overstated. The ongoing dialogue between privacy and utility, framed within the statistical challenges common to both SDC and DP, promises to yield exciting developments in the years to come.
